options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual discussions accompanied by canvas discussion responses

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Analytical thinking, improved essay writing skills
I learnt about a range of different types of world literatures, reading texts that I otherwise would have never read before.

This class is a necessary class, not only for the wide range of analytical and essay-writing skills that are developed but also the engaging and perception-changing discussions that accompany the graded work. One learns a deep history of Colonialism and the post-colonial environment as well as the ability to read and present findings of academia.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was very strongly designed to give english majors a good view of global literatures, and it definitely improved my reading and writing skills. I wish that the texts we read were slightly more diverse, to give a better view of the newer developments in global english literatures.

Strengths: the sheer amount of material that is read allows for a very broad-yet-specific dive into works from authors around the globe; the focus on the nature of language and linguistic imperialism allows for a guided review of the literatures of many different countries and regions including the Caribbean, Ireland, Canada, South Africa, and India.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The small size of the class was conducive to having productive discussions despite the challenges of a virtual seminar.
Worked very well through the virtual discussion format, and I thought the Canvas discussion posts were a helpful add in preparation for the Zoom discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, highly recommend it. Prof. Cleary is a fantastic teacher and very passionate about what he teaches.

Yes, for sure. Professor Cleary is excellent at taking us through the individual texts and challenging our thoughts about the authors' work. It is a good foundation for anyone who might want to dip their toes in global literature analysis.

I highly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in reading a vast quantity of literature from a variety of different regions and time-periods. The course examines racial, religious, national, and ethnic identities through a lens of Colonialism, examining the nature of linguistic imperialism through authors such as Ngugi Wa Thiong'o, James Joyce, Jamaica Kincaid, Claude McKay, Arundhati Roy, and J.M. Coetzee. The discussions were always very engaging, and the workload is balanced nicely throughout the semester. The workload comes out to about a book a week/week-and-a-half; however, the fast-paced nature of the course allows for the examination of multiple different texts. This course opened my eyes to a whole new realm of discussions -- about European Colonialism and linguistics -- and I could not recommend this class more, whether you are an English major or just someone who is interested in literature.

We talked extensively about problems with representation or authorship in world literature, yet I felt authors from certain cultures (such as Indigenous or East Asian) may not have been represented well in the syllabus. That said, the novels and other works chosen for this class were interesting not just by themselves but also in conjunction with each other. I would highly recommend this class for those interested in issues with postcolonial representation in literature and Prof. Cleary in particular, since his leadership in discussion shaped the lively and thoughtful conversations we had.
